I am sure that most folks are familiar by the odd shape hot sauce that you find at almost any restaurant named Sriracha.  It has become a favorite for the foodie set and some folks swear by it.
Griffin Hammond in his documentary, Sriracha has created in a 30 minute film, a concise history and the story behind the story.  Founded by Chinese native David Tran after he fled Vietnam, Sriracha was a product created as a taste of home on the Vietnamese dish Pho.
A mix of peppers, water, bit of garlic, and lots of love, Sriracha has had a steady growth and has been found as far as on the Space Station and used all over the world.  An American product, Sriracha is a truly entrepreneur success story.
Check out this spicy tale of an iconic hot sauce in a witty and fun style that celebrates the wonder of Sriracha.  I saw this film as part of the Atlanta Film Festival.  I highly recommend and will have you craving some Sriracha!

What a great story this is! Take that, anti-immigrant bigots. Bet most of you have a bottle of sriracha in your house.

This movie is more than about the now iconic American/Thai/Vietnamese/Chinese hot sauce that anyone who understands the flavor benefits of spicy knows. Before watching this movie I had researched Sriracha because I am fascinated by the rise of spicy in American Culture's food. If you took Mr. Tran's business model to any IV League College's Business Department, Corporate Business, or Investor they would likely treat you like an annoyingly optimistic mosquito and wouldn't let you get through the elevator speech, never mind a business plan presentation. You won't increase the price as demand grows? You want to single source the ingredients? You have basically no budget or staff for advertising? You are not going to patent the flavor or even trademark the name!?! I can see the veins pumping in the lawyer's and MBA professional's heads and them losing all bowel control due to confusion when they find out that this was Rooster Sriracha Sauce's history. And I think I know why. Because Mr. Tran's business model was based on his belief in the integrity of his product and being able to share his gift with the entire without shoving it down your throat through advertising or pricing you out of the experience by jacking up the price. He saw as his sauce's popularity grew that he was making the world a better place for his "Chili Friends".

The movie conveys these points in a concise and clear way but what is awesome is that the archetypes established are in fact true! Mr. Tran shows that the core of capitalism is essentially good. He also is a case in point of how many of the trappings of modern capitalism (advertising, price gouging for profit, using the law to remove competitors, not paying a fair price for your source materials) are not necessary if you make a quality product. The effort put towards the above gets in the way of or becomes more important than actually making a quality product that can stand alongside any competitor that arises.

Though only 33 minutes long, Griffin Hammond's little documentary about the ever-popular hot sauce is entertaining throughout and worth the look. Sriracha sauce has grown by leaps and bounds in popularity until now (2015) it has entered the mass culture and inspired sriracha mayonnaise and even potato chips. Talk about coming out of left field, who would have expected a Southeast Asian condiment like this to ever capture America's palate? I first encountered it in Vietnamese restaurants in San Francisco in the late 70's and early 80's and never thought it would migrate out of those places.

I won't be giving too much away to say that Huy Fong Sriracha sauce, the one with the rooster on the bottle is the ubiquitous brand of choice, and is made in one factory in Southern California. All the red jalapeno peppers used in it come from a single farm just an hour or so away from the factory. So despite the many foreign languages on the bottle, it's made right here in the U.S.A. We even get to meet the man who created this particular recipe and who runs the Huy Fong company, David Tran. He was a Chinese man living in Vietnam and was forced to emigrate with all other Chinese when the formerly North Vietnamese government took over. He's a friendly, unassuming man who is obviously really into his product.

During the quickly-passing half hour you will learn far more that you ever thought you would learn about the popular hot sauce. Totally fun when you have a little spare time.

If they are leaving out something like that lawsuit, what else are they not bringing up? This film was funded in part on Kickstarter, and we enjoyed scanning the names of all those who donated at the end.

Also, Mr. Tran is incredibly likable, and ethical as he never felt he could trademark the name sriracha because he didn't invent the idea, just one of the most popular recipes. We love seeing those types on ethics in business people! Overall, the film is bright, colorful, well-edited, well-scored, and uplifting, so what's not to love in the end?

Remarkable documentary about the 'best hot sauce in the U.S.'. As most people who were interviewed in this documentary, I had no idea how it was made. I knew it was a U.S. Product and made in California.

David Tran, an immigrant from Vietnam, arrived in the U.S., and settled in California. He lived with many other Vietnamese families, and what they missed was their hot sauce. Hot sauce, Sriracha, is a staple in Vietnam. David went about making his own Chile sauce and selling it to Vietnamese neighbors. He would hand pick the chiles and make the sauce by himself. Soon the Sriracha was selling like hot cakes, and to this day he cannot keep up with the demand. There are more orders than he can make. He has several large factories in California and puts out 18,000 bottles a day, 24/7. He is a man without an ego, and he must be worth a fortune, but he works everyday at the factory, supervising. His family works with him. A wonderful man who keeps the price low, and will only stop making Sriracha when people do not want it any longer.

We also travel to Thailand, where Sriracha came from originally. A woman in the seaside town of Sracha made the hot sauce. It has a little different taste. There are many many different types of Sriracha. David Tron has no patent, and I gather has no plans to get one.

We meet many people in the documentary who love Sriracha, we hear phone calls and see emails sent by fans to the Sriracha plant. This hot sauce has taken over the world, and most chefs agree there is always one bottle in their kitchens.

Who knew that the popular Sriracha sauce was a Korean sauce created in the United States by an ethnic Chinese forced out of Vietnam?  OK, probably lots of people, but before this documentary all I knew was that David Tran had lived in Vietnam.  Now I know, and knowing is half the battle (adding Sriracha to your food is the other half).  David Tran's story alone was worth the watch, and I wish the filmmaker had delved more into that, but from his interviews, my guess is that David Tran wants his sauce to speak for him.  Highly recommend this short, lighthearted documentary.

Entertaining and informative story of the maker of America's best known Sriracha and the chili sauce's origins in Southeast Asia. In 1970, David Tran leaves Vietnam and starts making and delivering his sauce to local restaurants in Los Angeles. You'll learn how Huy Fong Foods  got its name and the inspitation for its logo. This humble man and his company sold over 20 million bottles in 2012 without any advertising. You'll also travel to Thailand to learn about its Asian roots.
